Starlings form murmurations during migration. They roost without nests during that time. In summer, though, the adults will nest and raise one or two rounds of nestlings. The funniest part of that was our peafowl. One of our young peacocks was very curious about the nest, and he would occasionally poke his head into the area where they were nesting. I am writing a science fiction book using this principle for drone fighters in space. This is what I discovered.
First, why do they flock? Small birds and fish avoid predators. The larger birds don't flock the same way, not just because they are larger and their flight characteristics are different, but because they are not avoiding predators.
Because there are so many variables, it seems completely random, but there are patterns to it, if you look close enough.
First a unit moves in the same direction as their neighbors. Second, they remain close to their neighbors and third, avoid collisions with their neighbors. Modify that model using concentric zones for alignment, attraction and repulsion and you get an even better model.

Size of bird impact it's maneuverability, but I think there is another reason for different kind of flocking. Their fly in flocks for different goals. Small birds hunts insects in flocks (as do fishes), but big migratory birds like whooping crane, they migrates. Hunting flock has to adjust their velocity as insects trying to avoid them. Migrating birds aligns for flight efficiency. Smaller (5-15 birds) migratory flock birds tend to form V-shaped formation, catching up wind part of swirl formed at wing tip of bird in front.

"Different than" and "different from" mean different things, and are used in different ways. When comparing two nouns, one is "different from the other", not "different than the other".

"Different than" should only be used for clauses, and effectively means means "from what [...]" (so something can be "different than you expected", meaning "different from what you expected", but one flock isn't different "than" another).

I don't really think its math at all, or based on the smallest or largest's maneuverability. All of the birds are flying, trying not to run into eachother, and are trying to be as close to the middle of the flock as possible to avoid predators. It's kind of safety in numbers meets going really fast and needing to not run into eachother.

Imagine a group of 100 penguins for example, walking slowly, and everyone is trying to get to the middle to avoid being eaten by sea lions around the perimeter. They bump into eachother and shift and move around to get to the middle, no math or other thought involved.

Now imagine those same penguins are going 10x as fast and can't change direction as fast because of that. They become a messy ball of scrambling penguins that are trying to stay together. The whole group probably moves around as a whole a bit, some go flying out of the group and try to scramble back, they are mostly trying not to bump eachother but it's not too important. They are all still just trying to stay as close to the middle as possible.

Now the penguins (and I guess the sea lions in this example?) are can fly. If they run into eachother, they fall out of the sky and die. If they are all fairly unmaneuverable like the herons in the video, they all kinda pick a direction and stick to it other than trying to overlap and get to the middle. If they are super maneuverable like the smaller birds, the whole cluster kind of moves in whichever direction the average bird is going to try and get to the middle.

Then throw some wind into the mix, and I guess some hawks instead of flying sea lions if you're boring, and I think you have what's happening. It's all just compound movements of individual birds trying to survive in a flying group.

I think it's a little "wrong" to say Boids algorithm is how birds fly. The birds don't do math in their heads anymore than we do math when we walk in crowds. Boid algorithm is about emergent behavior, and about how simple individual behavior can create a seemingly complex group behavior. The math DESCRIBES the reality, it approximates. The math IS NOT the reality.

I worked with flocking algorithms in college, not sure if Boids, but had very similar elements. I found the higher the visual radius, the more the flock behaved like a school of fish. The real fun was when you throw in a predator or two in the mix, they would follow the same flocking rules, like being attracted to the center of mass, but the main flock would react with a flee motion (getting away from the predator). The flee motion was increased by the inverse of the distance between the predator an prey, that is, the closer the predator is, the more the prey forgets about the flock and just runs for its life. I found myself mesmerized, staring at the screen for hours. Good times.

I've heard that each bird (or schooling fish) tries to match vectors with it's 7 closest neighboring birds (or fish).

Fish are even more interesting in that many species of schooling fish have poor eyesight so they utilize a different sensory organ to match vectors. For the Ocean Skate, the skin on each side actually has thousands of tiny tuned resonant cavities in it which senses both electrical signals and mechanical signals and funnels them via an individual nerve directly to the spine of the central nervous system.

They can detect changes in pressure from the body and fin movements of neighboring fish as well as the electrical signals from the muscles of nearby fish. It's this system of electromechanical cavities that allow the skate to school effectively and effortlessly.

I've read this paper once, I can't remember the name to tell you though, about the movements of flamingos when they are on the ground.
It's like when one sees danger, it moves away from it, and the one next to it tends to just follow the first one (left, right, back, up) if the first one moves harshly, eventhough the second bird does not see any danger. Doing so, the second bird would be safe, whereas if it stooped to look for what's scaring the first one, it could get eaten without knowing where it came from. Then, the same behavior of following the previous one would be repeated by the third, second, third flaming and so on.
Fish do the same thing.

Sorry if this has been covered already but the large birds flying in formation and not like the flock of smaller birds may not be due to the size and/or maneuverability of the birds. Ducks come to mind. Ducks are very agile and have great maneuverability in flight yet they still fly in formation and in the same direction. I think it has more to do with the fact that waterfowl fly in ways that conserve energy. On the other hand, the seemingly random movements of the flock of smaller birds seems to be more of a "safety in numbers" instinct to try to stick as close as possible to others around without running into them to avoid predation. Also I think this, the three perameters that are basically being followed, creates the smaller groups that often break off then rejoin the rest of the group. This requires much more energy output by each individual in the flock and in no way conserves energy so they can maintain long periods of flight and long distance movement as does the flight/flock patterns of waterfowl. I'm just rambling my thoughts here now. Either way it's all very interesting to think about and witness.

The ability of any given group of birds to create these flight patterns on a given scale should be a function of their maneurerablility. That just seems logical.
I don't think maneuverablity is the reason cranes don't show the same patterns though. In fact, I wouldn't expect cranes to operate based on the same rule set.

As far as I know, these patterns are also useful to avoid getting picked off by predators easily. Cranes are most likely not hunted the same way that these smaller birds are, because e.g. for their long distance travels they fly significantly higher, where they are not easily reached.
My intuition is that their stronger emphasis on alignment during flight is because their behavior is focused more on exploiting each others slipstreams. Assuming they also have only three rules, they might be closer to something like: 1) If you see them, align with the highest rank bird (as far as I know this would be the oldest female. At least some migrating birds do it this way.) 2) Exploit slipstreams 3) keep pace (I once read that migrating birds rotate through, who has to fly in front of the V-formation, since the ones at the tip have it the hardest. What I mean by this rule is: If you are at the tip, stay there until you fall behind. More rested birds will take over. You also need to keep pace to stay in each others slipstreams.)

Cool video. I work for an electric utility and we had a location on our system that kept having outages at certain times of day. We figured out that we had overhead lines near a train switchyard. The trains were hauling grain and would periodically spill it so the birds would congregate on our lines near the spilled food. When the trains would link up it made a loud noise and scare the birds. They would all take off at the same time and would cause the phases to smack together. Causing an intermittent power outage. We asked the train operator to park the trains somewhere else along the lines and the problem went away. There’s probably a food source nearby which is why they congregate in that same place.

the three parameters listed makes sense:
1. Move to the center of mass: being in the flock, instinct drives the flock together because there is safety in numbers
2. Not hit each other: don't hit others and hurt yourself
3. Go with the group around you to stay in a flock and not get left out to be picked off by predators, naturally smaller groups fall into larger groups, larger flock larger chance for survival

Hey Destin! Another tid-bit about bird formations (but you might already know this) : The flying V formation is thought to be used for its aerodynamic efficiency. As a bird soars or flaps its wings, it creates a rotation vortex of air at its wingtips. Directly behind the bird, there is a downwash (which hinders aerodynamic efficiency if flown into). But behind and to the side of the bird, there's an upwash, making it easier for the next bird to fly!

In the same way, the birds do what we do : they all converge towards a center of mass (we all strive towards certain goals), they try not to hit each other (we try not to hurt or go against other people), and they try to fly in the same direction (we follow the opinion of others to fit in). As such, opinion can be the result of everybody's input, while being no one's particular responsibility. But if this might have positive effects sometimes, it can lead a whole society to go astray. Destin this is the most excited I've been for any video, ever. You show such a magnificent phenomenon so well (as usual). I've been doing hours and hours of research in to emergent behaviour of complex systems for a subject of my honours study at university.
Right now my research is based on finding a quantitative measure for the degree of emergence in a complex system. It's so fascinating because it is directly correlated to real-world systems that we can observe in nature!


Here's an example that might interest you Destin: we can use dynamical systems theory (spatial coherence, entropy) to measure the interactions between agents (boids in this example) to produce a quantitative measure of emergence. If the boids were like particles in a gas cylinder, they would have high entropy but low spatial coherence, so there would be little emergence. If the boids were like a crystal where there is high spatial coherence but low entropy, there would be low emergence (think of those big slow birds). As Ben said, the variables have to be fine-tuned to observe and measure highly emergent behaviour.



You might be surprised to learn about the depth of the philosophies behind emergence and how macro properties are caused by micro events. Strong vs weak emergence, downwards causation, etc.
It can even be extended in to consciousness science, and how electrical activity in our brains causes the emergent behaviour of our experience of consciousness. We may be one step closer to unravelling the mysteries of the most complex gift that God has given us.

As an ornithologist, I think of these movement patterns in different ways. You may be right about the differences in flocking behavior due to size and flight abilities of birds, but I think it also has to do with risk that the different species are exposed to. Large flocks of small birds (the blackbirds and starlings) also attract predators. That risk of predation from hawks and falcons will elicit different responses, which includes more dramatic changes in direction. The flocks of small birds react much more like schools of fish (say sardines) that are attacked by both fish and bird predators. In contrast, cranes or geese flying in flocks are much more immune to predation by hawks and falcons because they are just to big. The only predatory birds able to kill the larger birds are much less abundant eagles. (I'm definitely not saying these large birds are entirely immune, but the relative risk of predation is much different). These differences likely also lead to differences in behaviors.
Now, to switch things up, bird (and other animal movements) are also dependent upon finding food (not just avoiding being food). So cranes walking around may be looking at other cranes that are feeding and moving to locations where the see evidence that food is present. These movements are more likely be to very directional, which will be quite different from movements to avoid predation. In addition, it looked to me like there were two different subspecies of sandhill cranes in the fields (lesser and greater). The size differences between these could also influence movement, with the greater sandhills being able to defend slightly larger areas than the lessers.
Lots to think about that influences how animals move. One avenue that you might really like is to look at foraging movements and game theory applications. This is especially well developed for flock foraging waterbirds where some find food resources (producers) and other follow them to "share" resources (scroungers). That would be a cool video!

In fish, there's a distinction between schooling behaviour and shoaling behaviour. I think schooling behaviour is largely done by prey animals who have a set of behaviours that help in predator avoidance, and shoaling behaviour is done by any social fish that wants to be in proximity to other fish. I guess the big difference is that fish in a school orient themselves in the same direction as fish around them and fish in a shoal do not. I think the directional orientation adaptation helps with predator avoidance because tesselating or intricately repeating patterns confuse the brain particularly well. For instance, whenever I walk across a certain crosswalk made of tesselating hexagons and look down I start to feel dizzy and spatially disoriented but walking across forest rubble of similar sizes to the hexagons does not do this to me.

I think it's related to why the flock has taken flight. Part of it is believed to be a response to the presence of predators - there's safety in numbers. Their erratic weaving and fluttering may confuse the vision of predators, and each bird is always trying to minimize the amount of time it spends on the outside of the flock. If the cranes were motivated by similar factors, we'd probably see similar (albeit slower) emergent behavior, but all the cranes are doing is flying from one place to another. Their threats are not in the skies, but on the ground.

i always loved to odd divide invoked by the word "emergent". imo all behaviors of the universe are emergent, or seemingly so as we uncover the fundamental "rules" of the universe. this distinction "emergent" is used because of our discomfort with how all things seem to function this way, yet we do not wish ourselves to be under the same umbrella. we wish for autonomy. we wish to believe our sense of volition is absolutely us making a choice, not that the choice is an emergent behavior resulting from the rules we uncover. there's a lot of subtext whenever "emergent" is used ha.

Hi Destin, these murmurations are a common sight over in the UK. The birds we see doing this is the European starling, which tends to move around in flocks. This behaviour is usually observed just before they go to roost in evergreen trees, as dusk is falling. It is very common for the starlings to be predated by birds such as falcons and hawks at this time of day, and when they leave the roost in the morning. It is thought that the murmuration flight pattern is one way of confusing a predator and improving the odds of finding a branch to roost on! Starlings tend to roost together in the fall and winter, as spring and summer are the times for making nests and raising their young.
It's a truly amazing sight and, if you get close enough, the whirring sound made by their wings, as well as their calling to each other, is quite something to hear as well!

It's a fascinating field of study in general - the emergence of complex phenomena from simple rules for the interaction between a system's components, and the structures and dynamics of those emergent phenomena.

There's some great works on this topic out there - like "Self-Organization in Biological Systems" by Scott Camazine et al. - and an entire field of studies called "Synergetics", developed by the laser-researcher Hermann Haken in the 70s on the basis of statistical physics and non-equilibrium thermodynamics. Using elements from control-theory and dynamical-systems-theory, it wields mathematical tools to deal with the dynamics and phase-transitions of emergent phenomena like the flocking behavior of birds, fish schools, the structure of the Belousov-Zhabotinsky-reaction or of Rayleigh-Bénard-convection.

Well worth looking into :)

It's also related to the studies of complexity, chaos, patterns, information and entropy - a whole other treasure-trove of fascinating questions and insights. And it's what many scientists interested in the emergence of complexity and capturing these phenomena scientifically end up researching and talking about. There's this saying I've heard: "Old physicists never die, they go to Santa Fe to talk about complexity" - and honestly, I couldn't blame 'em. It's absolutely fascinating stuff.

For me there's one big thing (albeit obvious) you didn't mention : why the animals follow these rules
Flock of birds or schools of fish drive their strength from their numbers. Not for attack, but defense. It's way harder for predators to focus on a prey in a group of thousands.
There is one counter to this strategy, only employed by the smartest predators (dolphins for example) : cooperation.
Go watch a group of dolphins circle a school of fish, reducing it to a dense ball of fish, bring it to the surface so they have one less direction they can escape to, and then, taking turns, jumping from below to catch a (few) mouthfuls.
Tldr: Nature is amazing, dolphins are smart fuckers

When people drive, are they flocking?

Three rules 1) Atracted to each other 2) maintain distancing 3) match vector.

Starting with vectors, trafic rules have each vehicle on the road drive on either the left or right side of the road, depending on where in the eorld you are, which makes driving much safer and trafic flow more efficent. We have all probably heard some general rule of thumb, keep a certain minimum distance between you and a car infront of you based on you current driving speed and road condition. But are drivers attracted to other drivers?

I belive there is some evidence for it. First thing is we can exclude slow drivers blocking other drivers thus forming a train of vehicles. But pay attention at night. Often youll see on a wide open almost deserted roads, wolf pack like travel of 2 and 3 vehicles traveling together, often to the endangerment of another given that rural drivers need to watch out for dear on the side of the road in addition to the vehicle infront.

Furthermore, many drivers will report that sometimes they pick a pace car, someone to follow. That is evidence of attraction. Don't let them get to far away, or maybe it is just an example of match their speed and direction. So is matching vector (speed and direction) an emergent behavior resulting from attraction and keep distance ?

Give Visual Range a vector, that operates on the flight vector. Birds have visual fields with areas of binocular vision (depth perception), monocular vision (detection), and areas of effective blindness. The visual fields vary between types of birds, and the visual fields have horizontal planes (effectively) and vertical planes.
Most birds cannot move their eyes, so the visual range would be limited by the mobility of their skulls on their spines, and the attitude of their spines is limited when in flight.
Adding a vector mask based on these things will give a more realistic pattern. Adding the mask to the density avoidance will also add to realism, with group reaction based on the vector.
This should give better splitting / regrouping realism.

I would think the model could be adjusted (assuming it hasn't been already) to take into account mass, wing-span and other factors to model the whooping crane behavior, and perhaps add a gravitational force and surface plane toward from which it acts to do the same modeling of ground flocking behavior. Wing span and velocity would affect air instability behind a given bird in flight (and now we drift into particle physics modeling if we want to get just wacky with it), and mass and velocity might affect when a bird starts slowing and changing course to avoid impacts.

This is pretty phenomenal as a mathematical model of such a 'natural' behavior - but to be fair - that's what this is, a model of nature. Nature isn't really 'executing' the model, the birds aren't making mathematical decision per se, but their decisions are seemingly simplistic enough (given the right variables) to effectively model some assumed behaviors that very much mimic the natural observations.

Fascinating stuff nonetheless.

This is actually a great example of why math is so good at explaining stuff in reality. The birds aren’t doing much if any math. Animals want to be at the center of the flock/herd, because that’s where they’re safest from predators. If you’ve ever accidentally walked into someone, you know how unpleasant it is, and you didn’t do it a few hundred feet over the ground. Finally, the birds match velocities because that will keep the flock together in the future, and it makes it much easier to keep track of your neighbors and avoid collisions. The importance of these three things in their decisions is proportional to relative position, and so if you identify the behaviors, and in what way they are proportional to position, you can approximate it with a mathematical model. Parameters of the model can then be adjusted to best fit observations of reality, and the inaccuracies will quickly disappear. tl;dr Math is useful and amazing because even though few things in nature actually use numbers, numbers can describe them anyways

These kinds of emergent behaviors can be seen in "flocking humans" as well. In large groups of people like on a busy sidewalk or a mall or a cramped festival. It's interesting that for how incredibly complex we humans are we can still be reduced to extremely simple rules in certain situations. Very simple rules that in a large group creates a complex flock system that in itself acts almost like a separate intelligent entity.
Emergent complexity from simple rules can also be seen in the creation of life. Simple physics and chemistry creates cell-like structures that capture some amino acids that happened to form a structure that can guide creations of other structures or itself. This forms a new set of emergent rules that can combine to more complexity and so it goes with some slow and delicate nudging of natural selection until one day you have among many other things some hairless monkeys capable of contemplating the rules that give rise to the murmurations of Starlings

12:22 Birds don't really make urine. We pee because we excrete nitrogen as water-soluble urea, which is very mildly toxic (so there has to be some water in the bladder, can't just be urea). Birds excrete uric acid instead, and it's insoluble so there's almost no water in there. Obviously an advantage not to have to fly around with that water (and not have to drink it to begin with)... but on the other hand, the biochemical pathways to make uric acid are more complicated and require more energy than making urea. So the tradeoff is not worth it in many other situations. Aquatic animals can save even more energy by directly excreting ammonia, which is too toxic to be practical for terrestrial animals.

I think you're missing the boat on a couple of things here. First, as another person noted, we are using math to quantify a natural/biologic behavior, not the other way round. The birds are merely reacting to the other birds.



The second point you seem to be missing, that also has nothing to do with math, is motivation. What is motivating the birds do this? The answer is food in most cases. They are flying after insects that you can't see. As one bird sees the insects, other birds will turn to follow as the insects are swarming for protection from the birds and will be in large groups. Where there is one bug, there are probably many so the birds follow the ones turning in hopes of sharing in the meal, even though they may not see the swarm of insects themselves. I've seen this same kind of behavior in schooling fish in the ocean.


As for the larger birds, the motivation is different for them. They seek food on the ground because they don't have the agility to take food aloft. Their bodies are longer and larger which is perfect for long straight flights such as migration which is what they do.



As for math being used to quantify nature, we see this in aircraft design, especially in the form of military aircraft. Small fighter that need to be agile tend to have shorter wings and fuselages that allow them to turn on a dime to attack small moving targets of opportunity. But bombers, designed to fly to and attack a larger stationary target, have longer wing spans and fuselages that are great for long, straight flights to their predesignated targets.

Back in the 1960's my family had just moved into a brand new subdivision in the western suburbs of Washington DC. Near us was a natural area following the path of a stream, about 1/3 mile wide and many miles long. One year the area had a population explosion of starlings who flew in this manner but with a difference. For several months, I would wake up and look out my window to see what appeared to be a column of smoke rising from the forest, but was actually tens of millions of birds taking off from the trees to fly into Washington to feed during the day. The stream of birds would begin at some point down stream, which I couldn't see, and the source point of the birds taking off would slowly move up the valley as the birds left the immediate area heading for town. This would go on for about an hour or more, slowly making its way upstream until the source of the column was so far away I could no longer see it. The best comparison I can describe was like watching a steam locomotive spouting billowing black smoke as the train ran down the track. The huge number of birds created a major problem with buildings in DC. Many of the government buildings, such as the federal triangle, White House, Smithsonian and Capital, had to put electric fence wires on all the horizontal ledges and window sills to keep the birds from perching on the face of the buildings where their acidic droppings were covering the building walls and causing deterioration of the marble and granite facings. I have never seen anything like it before or since.

In addition to body size and maneuverability, I think ecology plays an important factor in the difference between a flock of small birds and a flock of large birds. Individual small birds (sparrow or pigeon size, etc) are vulnerable to aerial predators (peregrine falcons, etc). Turning and flashing as a flock can majorly confuse predators, increasing the survival chances of birds in the flock. Large birds like cranes don't have to worry as much about smaller, more agile raptors. Most aerial raptors target smaller prey birds anyway, and larger raptors don't go after aerial preys.

I like when you analyze biological systems. I would say we are using mathematics to describe what the birds are doing, not so much that the birds are acting on mathematical descriptions. There are likely many factors that code doesn't take into account.

Most of my life I have wondered and in some cases argued with people who assign “why” answers to interesting observations.
Example: why do we have lips. We have lips because they help us keep our food in our mouth and to help us communicate.

My answer or comment often goes something like this.

Yes, we do use our lips to help keep our food in our mouths and yes we use our lips to communicate. But that doesn’t answer why.

Now comes the evolution or creation arguments. Which will actually explain a version of why. And yes, evolution and creation can provide explanations of why but both can be argued and why never is agreed to.

To say that birds make decisions based on math is another version of why.

Please indulge me. I can agree that bird behavior can be described by math. I don’t agree that birds use math. I don’t agree that math is the foundation of their behavior. Yes, math can describe behavior but it can’t be assigned to the bird. Rather math can be assigned to us. It is us who seek to understand why and when we find an answer that appears to provide the solution we ascribe it to answer “why.”

I suspect that my comment here appears prima facia to contradict or argue. Rather, my attempt here is to explain my lifelong search for why but most of the time I don’t accept our understanding as the answer to why. I accept our answer as a description or a good guess. But why is a very elusive question/answer and I am suspicious of people whose answers claim to answer the question.

Interesting effect: set up a good microphone (directional, if possible) that goes below 20Hz. Then do a live spectrogram of the LF sound (below, say, 200Hz) and compare it to the flight maneuvers of a flock of birds... some flocks do synchronize their wing movements and can thus produce a substantial amount of infrasound. Even though this is way below "audible" sound, sensitive people can "feel" the substantial acoustic energy that's emitted from certain flight patterns of flocks in close proximity - probably via their otolith organs...

The most interesting thing about bird murmuration is that as an example of an emergent property, it's a very simple model of how the brain creates consciousness out of the actions of trillions of neuronal firings. Just as no bird creates the movement or decisions of the amoeba-like "organism" of the whole flock, no neuron creates conscious thoughts and body actions. The feedback of all of them in mutual reaction to the environment and each other causes the emergence of the behavior of the flock with the birds, and the conscious awareness of a big brained animal like a human being.
